ğŸ’¯ Application state is just client-side cache of server data.

Most use cases don't need to keep server data and client-side cache in sync. Simplify your life and just invalidate + rehydrate on every mutation.

Your architecture becomes much simpler with react-query / swr. https://t.co/DaL4tBIt45

@singh_saihaj Somebody else setup graphql-code-generator for that React project, so we had to do useWhateverQuery instead of useQuery(gql`query whatever { ... }`), which means many unnecessary wrapper functions.
@laurieontech @dan_abramov @tlakomy I just use React Query which removed 90% of my useEffect use cases ğŸ˜…ğŸ˜†

@dan_abramov @tlakomy How else would you load data?  You have to do "something" on component initial render.  Forget suspense and all the new shiny things.  All fetching libraries are built off useEffect.  https://t.co/xBIx2gtad3

@zachcodes @cicloon I didnâ€™t say that you donâ€™t use useSWR or react-query. I also didnâ€™t say that you donâ€™t use the cache.

I said that you shouldnâ€™t confuse react-query or useSWR with state. Once you call useSWR and get data out of it, that *becomes* state. Itâ€™s not state in and of itself.

@zachcodes We tried migrating from Redux -> React Query @Basedash (medium-sized codebase) but found that the lack of normalization made things way more annoying to work with. Specifically optimistic updates.

Ended up migrating back to modern Redux (Toolkit), very happy with the decision.

@zachcodes Also RTK-query is a thing, and I'd argue it's at least just as good as react-query. It's significantly better than all the libraries you listed for optimistic updates.

1) rtk-query is a thing
2) Using react query and co. does not mean you don't have global state. Redux is the most boring, predictable, and debuggable tool for doing that.

So no, not pointless. https://t.co/INlxWmPABy

RT @zachcodes: Unpopular opinion:

Redux is pointless when using react query / Apollo client / swr

@zachcodes It isn't unpopular at all.  If all you do with Redux is caching server responses you don't need it at all. However, libraries like react-query/swr won't work as well as Redux if your backend doesn't return normalized data.

@zachcodes I doubt it , data generated on the client is the prime use case for redux / state Management libs, where as data coming from an external source like an API is where React query shines we need not maintain such data on the client to manage .. I still feel redux is here to stay.

@khabubu_phathu @brian_royalb Why fetch data from your server only to store it again on your client? Youâ€™re creating an additional place for the same information to sit? React query or SWC is more efficient at this and they help ensure your data isnâ€™t stale.

Delegate network state management to swr or react-query. 

For redux applications, chekcout RTK-query made by redux maintainers.

RT @zachcodes: Unpopular opinion:

Redux is pointless when using react query / Apollo client / swr

React Quey also provides many other hot functionalities. Like useMutation hook which is commonly used to create/update/delete remote data.

If youâ€™re interested to learn more, donâ€™t forget to check I recommend all the React developers,
https://t.co/SRh9SAdTFR

- It also removes the need for useState and useEffect hooks and replaces them with a few lines of React Query logic like isLoading, error response, returned data.
In the long run, it will definitely help you keep your application maintainable, responsive, and fast.

Benefits of React Query:

- Window focus refetching â€“ When a user leaves your tab, React Query marks the data â€œstaleâ€ and refetches it when that person returns.

- Request retry â€“ you can set a number of retries for any request to combat random errors.

React Query provides us custom hooks like `useQuery` to fetch data. 
Under the hood, these hooks manage lots of things such as `caching` data after the initial fetch, re-fetching data in the background, etc.
React Query is a library that gives #ReactJS the state management ability for any kind of asynchronous data.

@knox_trades Not gonna lie. Seeing you query the onchain data about a month ago kind of inspired this. "Wish I knew how to do that". Decided starting with Python as a base and then moving over to js/rust/react/anchor with the foundation would be a little easier. ğŸ™‚

Unpopular opinion:

Redux is pointless when using react query / Apollo client / swr

@abobakerhilal @tannerlinsley If you have no global state besides server-side and want to use react-query, you are totally fine to use it on it's own. 
If you have additional global state, you have to additionally use some global state mgmt library - RTK is one of those options.
I'm so glad that react-query from @tan_stack has a retry mechanism as my current projects api calls sometimes fails and then works a second or third time some authorization issue ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£ğŸ¤£
